questiontext.text:
A combination of objects takes no account of order whereas a permutation does. The formula \(^nP_r=\dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}\) gives us the number of ordered sets of \(r\) objects chosen from \(n\). Suppose the number of sets of \(r\) objects (taken from \(n\) objects) in which order is not taken into account is \(C\). It follows that
\(\qquad C\times r!=\dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}\)
and so \(C\) is given by the formula
\(\qquad C=\dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}\)
We normally denote the right-hand side of this expression by \(^nC_r\) so that
\(\qquad ^nC_r=\dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}\)
A common alternative notation for \(^nC_r\) is \(\left(\begin{matrix}n\\r\end{matrix}\right)\).
